title: 113_hr5635
content: The Act may be cited as the "Disclosing Aid Spent to Ensure Relief Act" or the "DISASTER Act". Congress finds that it is important to understand the amount and scope of the Federal Government's spending on disaster-related assistance to better inform budget decisions. Recovery efforts require significant resources for long-term restoration of infrastructure and commerce in affected communities. Understanding agency expenditures will aid in the appropriations process and budget requests. Understanding disaster-related expenses is crucial for informing budget decisions and reducing vulnerabilities to future natural disasters. The purpose of this Act is to require the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to annually submit to Congress a report on all disaster-related assistance provided by the Federal Government. The Act requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to submit an annual report to Congress on Federal disaster-related assistance, including obligations for disaster response, recovery, and mitigation efforts from various agencies and programs. The curr_chunk lists various agencies and programs involved in disaster-related assistance, including the Farm Service Agency, Food and Nutrition Service, Natural Resource Conservation Service, Forest Service, Rural Housing Service, Rural Utilities Service, National Marine Fisheries Service, Economic Development Administration, Army Corps of Engineers, and Department of Defense. The curr_chunk outlines different departments and programs related to disaster assistance, including the Department of Education, Department of Health and Human Services, and Department of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk provides details on disaster assistance programs from various federal agencies, including FEMA, HUD, Department of the Interior, and Department of Justice. The Department of Justice oversees legal activities, the United States Marshals Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Bureau of Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives, the Federal Prison System, and the Office of Justice Programs. The Department of Labor manages National Emergency Grants for Dislocation Events and the Workforce Investment Act Dislocated Worker Program. The Department of Transportation includes the Federal Highway Administration's Emergency Relief Program, the Federal Aviation Administration, and the Federal Transit Administration. The report required by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) includes details on disaster-related assistance obligations by agency and account, the overall amount of such obligations during the fiscal year, and the specific disaster for which the spending was obligated. The report mandated by FEMA includes information on disaster-related assistance obligations by agency and account, overall spending amounts, specific disasters, response and recovery spending, mitigation spending, loans, and grants. The report will be publicly available on the Office of Management and Budget website in a searchable, sortable, and downloadable format. The reporting requirement for disaster-related assistance will be effective with the President's budget submission for fiscal year 2017.
